headline: Rep. Andy Biggs 'excited' by Trump's push to cut spending
subHeadline: President Trump is looking to cut spending from the budget bill that was just passed. Rep. Andy Biggs of the House Freedom Caucus joins 'Your World' to discuss what he expects.

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Let's go to Arizona Republican Congressman Andy Biggs. He's a member of the Freedom Caucus. He voted against that spending measure. So I would imagine, sir, you welcome this latest development.

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDY BIGGS, R-ARIZONA
utterances.sentences: Yes.  I'm excited to see the recisions looks like. It's instituted by the White House. They initiate the action. So the president is going to have to make a list of unencumbered accounts that he wants to attack and pare back.  I'm excited to see what that list looks like. And I hope it's as expansive as President Reagan was in the early '80s, because President Reagan rescinded about $45 billion over the course of his presidency.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Now, what happens with other Republicans, though? They were just happy in the end, even though they didn't publicly say so, to wipe their hands of it and say, all right, we got this done and approved and we're out of here. Some of them might not be as happy.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that, in the end, we want to get toward a balanced budget. So, they may not be real happy that we're doing some paring and pruning afterwards, but this bush is overgrown. And it's time to cut it back. And I think that many of them are going to say, here's a chance to go back, because I don't think our base was real happy with us.  So, here's a chance to go back and say, look, we heard you, we're going to cut back some spending. And I think that's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Switching gears, if you don't mind, sir, we're getting word from Nancy Pelosi, and this leaked out from conversation and strategies she's wearing with colleagues, that if the Democrats were to retake the House, she wants to revisit your tax cut, Republicans tax cut, the one that became law, and just, you know, rip it apart, said that it was all tilted to the rich. You say what?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, say, well, that's why we need to win the midterms for the Republicans, because she's already talking about increasing personal income tax and the corporate income tax.   And this gets to my whole point all along is they just -- Democrats and many of them just fundamentally don't understand the economy. And the economy really moves and circulates and is stimulated when individuals keep their money, when corporations can keep their money and reinvest in their businesses and create jobs. And that's what we're seeing. We're having record revenue in the federal tax coffers because of the economy starting to really heat up. And that's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, but you're also having record deficits. So, I'm not saying that's exclusively your fault, but the Republicans are going to be the stewards of what will likely be a trillion-dollar deficit this year.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I'm not blaming that on the tax cuts. I'm not blaming that on anything but just more spending vs. more money coming in. So I guess what I'm asking you is what Republicans will counter with. If Democrats were to take over in the House, what would be your argument for keeping those cuts and trying to avoid deficits from getting worse?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that the fact that the reduced regulation in the tax reform has produced record revenue every month coming into the federal government for about six, seven months now. I think that's indicia that lower taxes actually increases federal revenue. And that's not intuitive. I realize that. But that's exactly what happens. We have seen it over and over again.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you know what has happened. I know you were trying to address this and some of your Freedom Caucus members are trying to address this. This is why you were concerned about that $1.3 trillion spending plan, because a lot of American voters, as you know, Congressman, are saying, well, you know, Republicans talk a good game on this, but they don't rein in spending.  And maybe Nancy Pelosi is right. You say what?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, I say that Americans may be right. The Republicans have got to cut spending. We have got to be tougher on that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you never do. You never do, never, ever, ever, ever.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, but that may be true so far. But that's -- I'm always an optimist. I believe that...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, you're running out of so far's, right, because November is not that far.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Yes.  That's why the recisions, I think, mean a lot. We can move some of that down. It's still going to be deficit spending, but -- but if we're going to say that the Democrats are going to bring a balanced budget, they're not going to. They are going to increase taxes, but they will reduce federal revenue. But in the meantime, they are going to continue to increase spending. Good grief, their spending proposal was a $10 trillion deficit over 10 years. That's...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's horrible.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: No, you raise a very good point. It's a little rich for Nancy Pelosi to come out and bemoan deficits and the rest.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But it is what it is. Right? It's a weird world.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Congressman, thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.  END  Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
